case_name: Arati Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Sawaldas Madhavdas

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 86 and 87 of 1956 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 86 and 87 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeals from Judgment and Order dated November 24, 1954, of Bombay High Court in Appeals Nos. 89/X and 96/X of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the Judgment and Order dated November 24, 1954, of the Bombay High Court in Appeals Nos. 89/X and 96/X of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 22, 1960 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-These two companysolidated appeals

facts.text: Two consolidated appeals arise out of Bombay High Court judgment dated November 24, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-These two companysolidated appeals arise out of the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated November 24, 1954,

facts.text: Messrs. Sawaldas Madhavdas brought suit against Arati Cotton Mills Ltd. on April 16, 1953 for rupees two lacs and odd.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are simple and may be very shortly stated. On April 16, 1953, Messrs. Sawaldas Madhavdas brought a suit against the Arati Cotton Mills Ltd., praying for a decree for rupees two lacs and odd.

facts.text: Suit decreed on July 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed on July 22, 1954.

facts.text: Arati Cotton Mills Ltd. filed memorandum of appeal on September 4, 1954 and paid court fees of Rs. 3,193-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: The Arati Cotton Mills Ltd. filed a memorandum of appeal against the said decree on September 4, 1954, and paid companyrt fees of Rs. 3,193-12-0 on the said memorandum.

facts.text: Settlement arrived between parties on or about October 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On or about October 5, 1954, a settlement was arrived at between the parties and on October 9, 1954,

facts.text: Prayer made for dismissal of appeal on October 9, 1954 for want of prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: a settlement was arrived at between the parties and on October 9, 1954, a prayer was made for dismissal of the appeal for want of prosecution.

facts.text: Arati Cotton Mills Ltd. made application under s. 151 CPC on November 18, 1954 for refund of excess court fees.

anchor.surface_text: On November 18, 1954, an application was made under s. 151, Code of Civil Procedure, by the Arati Cotton Mills Ltd., for refund of excess companyrt fees paid on the memorandum of appeal.

facts.text: In application, appellants claimed suit instituted on April 16, 1953 prior to Court Fees Bombay Amendment Act XII of 1954, only Rs. 32 payable under item No. 58.

anchor.surface_text: In the application it was stated The appellants say that the appeal having arisen out of a suit which had been instituted on or about 16th April, 1953, long prior to the companying into force of the Court Fees  Bombay Amendment  Act, XII of 1954, numbercourt fees were payable on the memorandum of appeal herein except as provided in the Table of fees hereinafter mentioned ... The appellants say that the only fee payable for the filing of the said memorandum of appeal was the fee of Rs. 32 under item No. 58 of the Table of fees

facts.text: Arati paid excess Rs. 3,161-12-0 by mistake.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants say that they were number legally bound to pay anything more than the said sum of Rs. 32 and that sum of Rs. 3,161-12-0 paid by them in excess of the said sum of Rs. 32 was paid by mistake

facts.text: Messrs. Rasiklal and Company Ltd. brought suit against Messrs. Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd. and two other defendants on December 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, on December 17,1953, Messrs. Rasiklal and Company Ltd., brought a suit against Messrs. Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd. and two other defendants

facts.text: Decree passed on May 11, 1954 for Rs. 44,876-12-0 against Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: in which a decree was passed on May 11, 1954, for a sum of Rs. 44,876-12-0 against Messrs. Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd.

facts.text: Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd. filed memorandum of appeal on July 31, 1954 and paid court fees of Rs. 1,958.

anchor.surface_text: The latter filed a memorandum of appeal on July 31, 1954, and paid companyrt fees of Rs. 1,958 on it.

facts.text: Appeal withdrawn with leave of High Court on September 27, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was, however, withdrawn with the leave of the High Court on September 27, 1954.

facts.text: Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd. applied for refund of excess court fees on similar ground.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Supreme General Films Exchange Ltd. then applied for refund of the excess companyrt fees paid on a ground similar to that mentioned earlier in companynexion with the application of the Arati Cotton Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Both applications heard together after notice to Advocate-General, Bombay, who opposed for State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Both the applications were heard together after issue of numberice to the Advocate-General, Bombay, who appeared for the State of Bombay and opposed the applications.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed the applications by judgment dated November 24, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment and order dated November 24, 1954, the High Court allowed the applications.

facts.text: State of Bombay obtained certificate that cases fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay then asked for and obtained a certificate in the two cases which were companysolidated to the effect that they were fit for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Court Fees Bombay Amendment Act, 1954 (Bombay Act No. XII of 1954) came into force on April 1, 1954.

facts.text: High Court referred to earlier decision in A Reference Under Section 5 of the Court Fees Act, 1954 57 Bom. L.R. 180.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the learned Chief Justice who delivered the judgment allowing the two applications, referred to an earlier decision of his, reported in A Reference Under Section 5 of the Court Fees Act  1  and aid that that decision governed the present cases also.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

The appellants say that the only fee payable for the filing of the said memorandum of appeal was the fee of Rs. 32 under item No. 58 of the Table of fees

arguments.claim: Right of appeal is a substantive right vesting at date of suit filing; appeal is continuation of suit; cannot be impaired by non-retrospective procedural enactment imposing onerous conditions like higher fees.

The State of Madhya Pradesh and Others and certain other decisions to which we shall presently refer, the learned Chief Justice held that a right of appeal is a substantive right which vests in a litigant at the date of the filing of the suit, and cannot be taken away unless the legislature expressly or by necessary intendment says so furthermore, an appeal is a continuation

arguments.claim: There is no vested right in procedure; presumption against retrospectivity does not apply to procedural enactments like court fee changes even if disadvantageous.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State of Bombay, appellant before us, the correctness of the decision has been challenged on the ground that there is no vested right in procedure and reliance has been placed on the principle that the presumption against a retrospective construction has no application to enactments which affect only the procedure and practice of the courts, even when the alteration which the statute makes may be disadvantageous to one of the parties see Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes, 10th Edn., p. 225

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as applying to mere procedure not impairing substantive appeal right; impairment of appeal right is substantive

arguments.claim: Mohri Kunwar v. Keshri Chand holds no vested right to old court fees for appeals filed after change.

anchor.surface_text: Very strong reliance has been placed on the decision in Mohri Kunwar v. Keshri Chand and on the observations made therein to the effect that no suitor has a vested right to insist that during the pendency of a litigation which a suitor has started, the enactment relating to court fee shall not be changed and the fee leviable shall not be increased or reduced with regard to future appeals

arguments.claim: Garikapatti Veerayya concludes that impairment or more onerous condition on appeal right is not retrospective absent express or necessary intendment.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it has been submitted that since the decision of the learned Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court in A Reference Under Section 5 of the Court Fees Act, there has been another decision of this Court which concludes the question Garikapatti Veerayya v. N. Subbiah Choudhury and it is argued that the true principle is that where a right of appeal is impaired or imperilled or a more onerous or stringent condition is put on the right of appeal, the impairment, peril or imposition of a more stringent condition is not retrospective unless

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion in Garikapatti Veerayya  1  is, however, this this Court referred with approval to decisions which accepted the position that taking away a right

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court approves principle and applies it

arguments.claim: No provision express or by necessary intendment giving retrospective effect to amendments affecting appeals from pre-amendment suits.

anchor.surface_text: The change was effected inter alia by deleting s. 4 and amending s. 6 of the Court Fees Act, 1870, and Art. 1 of Sch. I to the Act. There was no provision, express or by necessary intendment, for giving retrospective effect to the amendments made in the sense of affecting a right of appeal arising out of a suit instituted prior to the relevant date.

arguments.claim: Impairment of right of appeal by more onerous condition like increased court fees is substantive right matter, not mere procedure; governed by law at suit institution.

anchor.surface_text: So far as we have been able to appreciate the submissions made on behalf of the parties, the point of controversy is really this is an impairment of the right of appeal by imposing a more stringent or onerous condition thereon a matter of procedure only or is it a matter of substantive right ? We think that the question is really concluded by the decisions of this Court.

arguments.claim: Hoosein Kasam Dada holds that requiring tax deposit for appeal impairs substantive appeal right and has no retrospective effect absent express provision.

anchor.surface_text: We refer first to the decision in Hoosein Kasam Dada India Ltd. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and others. The facts of that case were these Section 22 1 of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, provided that no appeal against an order of assessment should be entertained by the prescribed authority unless it was satisfied that such amount of tax as the appellant might admit to be due from him, had been paid. ... It was held by this court that the appellant had a vested right of appeal when the proceedings were initiated in 1947 and his right of appeal was governed by the law as it stood then.

arguments.claim: Garikapatti Veerayya approves that increasing court fees impairs appeal right like taking it away; cites Sawaldas Madhavdas (this case) and others.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Garikapatti Veerayya v. Subbiah Choudhury, referred specifically to two decisions relating to an increase in court fees by subsequent amendment of the Court Fees Act, and one of the decisions was Sawaldas Madhavdas v. Arati Cotton Mills Ltd., the very decision which is under appeal here. The other decision was R. M. Seshadri v. The Province of Madras. ... The point of the decision in Garikapatti Veerayya is, however, this this Court referred with approval to decisions which accepted the position that taking away a right of appeal and imposing a more onerous condition on such right involved the same principles as to retrospective effect of the subsequent legislation.

arguments.claim: Mohri Kunwar distinguishable as it conferred new appeal right against fee deficiency order, not impairing existing appeal right.

anchor.surface_text: As to the decision in Mohri Kunwar v. Keshri Chand on which so much reliance has been placed by the appellant, it is necessary to point out that the question there was if the right of appeal created by s. 6A of the Court Fees Act, which was added by U. P. Act, XIX of 1938, was available as against an order passed after the coming into force of the latter Act ... That is a principle of a different character from the one we are concerned with in the present case, viz., the retrospective effect of a subsequent enactment which either takes away a right of appeal or impairs it by imposing a more stringent or onerous condition thereon.

arguments.claim: Nagendra Nath Bose holds new deposit condition for appeal against sale set aside order impairs substantive appeal right; no retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: Another decision in point is that of Nagendra Nath Bose V. Mon Mohan Singh Roy. In that case the plaintiff instituted a suit for rent valued at Rs. 1,306-15-0 and obtained a decree. ... By requiring such deposit as a condition precedent to the admission of the appeal, a new restriction has been put on the right of appeal ... This decision was approved by this Court both in Hoosein Kasam Dada and Garikapatti Veerayya.

holdings.text: There was no provision, express or by necessary intendment, for giving retrospective effect to the amendments made in the sense of affecting a right of appeal arising out of a suit instituted prior to the relevant date.

anchor.surface_text: The change was effected inter alia by deleting s. 4 and amending s. 6 of the Court Fees Act, 1870, and Art. 1 of Sch. I to the Act. There was no provision, express or by necessary intendment, for giving retrospective effect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of specific amendments (deletion of s.4, amendments to s.6 and Art.1 Sch.I) reveals no express words or necessary implication for retrospectivity.

holdings.text: [I]s an impairment of the right of appeal by imposing a more stringent or onerous condition thereon a matter of procedure only or is it a matter of substantive right? We think that the question is really concluded by the decisions of this Court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as we have been able to appreciate the submissions made on behalf of the parties, the point of controversy is really this is an impairment of the right of appeal by imposing a more stringent or onerous condition thereon a matter of procedure only or is it a matter of substantive right ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question concluded by Supreme Court precedents treating onerous conditions on appeals as impairing substantive rights rather than mere procedure.

holdings.text: [A]n impairment of the right of appeal by putting a new restriction thereon or imposing a more onerous condition is not a matter of procedure only it impairs or imperils a substantive right and an enactment which does so is not retrospective unless it says so expressly or by necessary intendment.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that in a long line of decisions approved by this Court and at least in one given by this Court, it has been held that an impairment of the right of appeal by putting a new restriction thereon or imposing a more onerous condition is not a matter of procedure only it impairs or imperils a substantive right and an enactment which does so is not retrospective unless it says so expressly or by necessary intendment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long line of approved precedents (Hoosein Kasam Dada, Garikapatti Veerayya, Nagendra Nath Bose) establish that fee increases impair vested substantive appeal rights without retrospectivity.

holdings.text: We are, therefore, of the view that the High Court was right in the view it took, and the orders of refund of excess court fees which it passed were correct in law.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the High Court was right in the view it took, and the orders of refund of excess court fees which it passed were correct in law. Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of non-retrospectivity principle and substantive right doctrine to facts confirms High Court correctly ordered refunds under s.151 CPC.

holdings.text: Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal conclusions on non-retrospectivity and substantive rights necessitate dismissal upholding refunds.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that in a long line of decisions approved by this Court and at least in one given by this Court, it has been held that an impairment of the right of appeal by putting a new restriction thereon or imposing a more onerous condition is not a matter of procedure only it impairs or imperils a substantive right and an enactment which does so is not retrospective unless it says so expressly or by necessary intendment.
